title: Good English and sharp communication skills 'key to getting a new job' says Robert Walters
text:

Thu, Jul 30, 2015, 15:18 BST - UK Markets close in 1 hr 12 mins Good English and sharp communication skills 'key to getting a new job' says Robert Walters By Elizabeth Anderson | Telegraph – 25 minutes ago 442.98 +3.4800 
The recruitment company reported a surge in pre-tax profits as workers grew more confident applying for new jobs 
Robert Walters (LSE: RWA.L - news ) joined a number of recruitment consultants benefitting from the UK’s recovering jobs market as it revealed pre-tax profits jumped by 74pc to £8.7m in the first half of the year. 
The FTSE 250 company, which specialises in financial services, said net fee income the amount recruiters are paid by companies for placing workers - rose by a fifth to £38.7m in the six months to the end of June. 
Chief executive Robert Walters said confidence has returned to the UK jobs market, with workers now more upbeat about applying for a new job. 
He also said that a combination of good communication skills, combined with technological ability, are key to landing good jobs, and recommended that job seekers across the world have a good grasp of English, which is “becoming the language of business”. 
“People are moving more frequently, which is better for us," said Mr Walters. "That’s happening across the UK, in London and the regions. Particularly encouraging is the impressive growth we are seeing from our newer businesses in emerging markets in Asia and further signs of a recovery in financial services." 
English is becoming the language of business and a good grasp of the language is essential, says Robert Walters 
Total (Swiss: FP.SW - news ) group revenue increased to £377.6m, up from £310m last year. Most of the business is exposed to the permanent jobs sector, which earns more money per person placed than the temporary recruitment sector. 
Other recruiters, including Michael Page and Hays (LSE: HAS.L - news ) , reported earlier this month that a rise in permanent job vacancies had boosted profits.
